articles.title: Global study revises greenhouse gas emissions for tropical inland waters
articles.summary: Tropical inland waters don't produce as many greenhouse gas emissions as previously estimated, according to the results of an international research collaboration led by Charles Darwin University. The study aimed to better understand GHG emissions in tropical rivers, lakes and reservoirs. It was published in the journal Nature Water.

articles.title: Settling the migration debate
articles.author: Tarric Brooker
articles.summary: The level of migration in Australia has been a source of controversy recently. The most recent data available extends only to March and will not be updated until shortly before Christmas. There are questions whether the leading indicators are representative of the true migration level in Australia.

articles.title: Unlivable: Confronting Extreme Urban Heat in Latin America and the Caribbean (World Bank Group)
articles.author: Public Technologies
articles.summary: Latin America and the Caribbean face a new climate reality: rising temperatures, more frequent heatwaves, and record-breaking extremes. The number of extremely hot days-those above the 95th percentile-is increasing, with the report Uninhabitable: Confronting Extreme Urban Heat in Latin America and Caribbean.

articles.title: Unions of Transboundary Ecosystems: A New Diplomatic Architecture
articles.author: Syed Wajahat Ali
articles.summary: Since the Paris Agreement, the UNFCCC has sped up the transition to renewable energy and fundraising for climate resilience. The Paris Agreement's nationally determined contributions (NDCs) are unevenly applied and misaligned with the aim to limit global warming to 'well below' 2°C by the end of the century and to keep warming within the safer limit of 1.5°C. Global average CO2 concentration has surged by 3.5 ppm from 2023 to 2024, the largest increase since modern measurements started in 1957.

articles.title: If the frigate bird stops returning to the Pacific, what could we lose with its flight?
articles.author: Seiuli Salamasina von Reiche
articles.summary: The Great Frigate Bird is a symbol of strength, freedom, and endurance. Rising seas, coastal development, and climate change are destroying the habitats they rely on. Siosenamele Lui from SPREP explains that if we lose these keystone species, we start to lose the language and the knowledge. Rooti Terubea from Kiribati, and George Quadina from Nauru are preserving the spirit of the frigate bird through the enduring traditional pastime of catching.

articles.title: Permafrost thawed by climate change threatens remote villages in Alaska
articles.author: News Feed Editor
articles.summary: Permafrost thawing by climate change threatens remote villages in Alaska PBS. The thaw of the permafrost is a result of climate change.    in the last few decades has thawed the permafrosts in Alaska.

articles.title: Permafrost thawed by climate change threatens remote villages in Alaska
articles.author: Ismael M. Belkoura
articles.summary: In Nunapitchuk, Alaska, climate change is forcing an Alaskan Native village to relocate due to melting permafrost. Edna Chase, 60, has to pump water from under her house every 15 minutes to keep it from flooding. Amalia Huot-Marchand and a team from Medill School of Journalism report.

articles.title: Hearing on Proposed Land Use Changes Rescheduled to Dec. 9 (Charlotte County, FL)
articles.author: Public Technologies
articles.summary: Hearing on Proposed Land Use Changes in Charlotte County, Florida, has been rescheduled to Dec. 9th. The transmittal hearing for proposed changes to the Rural Settlement Area Overlay District project (TCP-24-04) has been postponed.

articles.title: Australia's rainforests become the first in the world to make concerning switch
articles.author: Lauren Liebhaber
articles.summary: Australia's rainforests are the first in the world to switch from being a carbon sink to a net carbon source, according to a study published in Nature. The study analyzed data from 1971 to 2019 and determined that more trees are dying from climate-related changes such as extreme temperatures, dryness and drought. This loss is not being offset by new tree growth.

articles.title: Sea levels are rising faster than ever before, scientists warn
articles.author: Eliza Hajzeri
articles.summary: Sea levels are rising faster than at any other time in the last 4,000 years. Since 1900, global sea levels have risen at an average rate of 1.5 millimeters per year. Global warming and glacial melting are driving the acceleration of sea level rise. For every centimeter of rise, six million people are exposed to coastal flooding.

articles.title: Large chunk of suspected space debris found in Australian desert
articles.author: Denise Chow
articles.summary: A large chunk of suspected space debris has been found in the Pilbara region of Western Australia. It's not clear what the object is or where it came from, but officials say it's probably a spent rocket part. It was found in a remote part of the desert.

articles.title: Waterfowl season in Southwest Idaho started Sunday. Here's what to expect
articles.summary: The waterfowl season in southwest Idaho kicked off on Sunday. Before heading out, you should review the Idaho Migratory Game Bird 2025-2026 Seasons & Rules Brochure.    There are a few notable changes compared to last season.

articles.title: Weather Talk: Does hurricane season impact winter?
articles.author: Tony Pann
articles.summary: Tony Pann looks at the possible connection between hurricane season and the upcoming winter and what that might mean for the upcoming season.    Tony Panna is a meteorologist at CNN.com.  He is also a member of CNN Meteorologist Network.

articles.title: NASA reveals how certain atmospheric reactions mitigate nearly a third of global warming
articles.summary: Aerosols from dust, smoke, and sulfates are currently offsetting roughly a third of global warming. This interplay of forces influencing Earth's temperature underscores the need for refined climate models. Aerosols directly impact air quality, visibility, and human health.

articles.title: Records tumble across Australia after scorching Monday
articles.author: 9News Staff7:24am
articles.summary: Birdsville in Queensland reached 44.9 degrees yesterday, just 0.2 degrees short of the statewide October weather record. Moomba Airport in South Australia hit 44.1 degrees, breaking the previous record of 43.5 degrees. Oodnadatta registered 44 degrees just after 3.30 pm. Tibooburra in the far north-west of New South Wales also broke records to reach 42.6 degrees. The heat is set to move to the east coast by later in the week.

articles.title: Where Does Morocco Stand on Global Efforts to Stall Climate Change?
articles.author: Sydney Jezik
articles.summary: Carbon dioxide concentration in the atmosphere has risen by 3.5 parts per million (ppm) from 2023 to 2024. Last year's increase marks the largest annual rise since systematic measurements began in 1957. The UN has pleaded with countries to take concrete steps towards meeting their climate commitments.

articles.title: Europe's climate is changing fast: How it's affecting people and the economy
articles.author: Phys Dot Org
articles.summary: Temperatures across Europe are rising at twice the global average. This is leading to more frequent and intense heat waves, droughts, floods and storms. Climate change damages the environment as well as the human health.      Â

articles.title: The Southern Ocean may be building up a massive burp
articles.author: Phys Dot Org
articles.summary: The ocean has helped mitigate global warming by absorbing about a quarter of anthropogenic carbon dioxide emissions and more than 90% of the excess heat those emissions generate. Many efforts, including assessments by the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change, have looked at how the oceans contribute to global warming.

articles.title: North Pacific's Record-Breaking Heat Is an Anomaly
articles.author: Arden Dier
articles.summary: A vast swath of the North Pacific Ocean just logged its warmest summer ever. The so-called "warm blob" stretches from Asia's east coast to North America's west. Sea surface temperatures rose more than 0.25 degrees Celsius above the previous record. This spike is well beyond what most climate models predicted.

articles.title: Temperature yo-yo messes with my sleep
articles.author: John Hanscombe
articles.summary: Temperatures have been fluctuating wildly at night, keeping Barnaby Joyce awake at night. There was a sudden stratospheric warming event over Antarctica in September. It's resulted in a string of cold fronts preceded by warm and dry westerlies. The weather in Tasmania has been wet, windy and miserable. High minimum temperatures make sleep difficult.

articles.title: Temperature yo-yo messes with my sleep
articles.author: John Hanscombe
articles.summary: Temperatures have been fluctuating wildly at night, keeping Barnaby Joyce awake at night. There was a sudden stratospheric warming event over Antarctica in September. It's resulted in a string of cold fronts preceded by warm and dry westerlies. The weather in Tasmania has been wet, windy and miserable.

articles.title: Extreme fire danger risk declared as Illawarra temp to skyrocket to 36 degrees
articles.author: Cookie Pnigdbxqzpgpjmu
articles.summary: The temperature reached 32.1 degrees in Albion Park on Monday, October 20. The mercury will reach mid-20s on Tuesday and soar to a warm 36 degrees on Wednesday. Extreme fire danger rating has been declared for Wednesday. It comes in the wake of a bush and grass fire that burned through most of Windang Island on Sunday.

articles.title: HEADLINE: 'I Thought Climate Change Would End the World. I Was Wrong.' By Ted Nordhaus
articles.author: Stephen Heins
articles.summary: Ted Nordhaus used to believe that business-as-usual emissions would lead to around five degrees of warming by the end of this century. Now he believes it will be less than three degrees. The good news extends well beyond projections of long-term warming.

articles.title: Catastrophic flooding from typhoon Halong devastates Alaska native communities
articles.author: Mario Lotmore
articles.summary: Typhoon Halong's remnants struck the Yukon-Kuskokwim Delta on October 13-14, 2025. It disproportionately impacted Alaska Native villages, specifically the Yup'ik communities. In Kipnuk, 90% of homes were destroyed, in Kwigillingok, a third of them were swept away. Alaska National Guard and U.S. Coast Guard conducted urgent search-and-rescue operations. Governor Mike Dunleavy requested a Major Disaster Declaration from President Donald Trump through FEMA.

articles.title: Whitehouse Warns IMF: Caving to Political Pressure on Climate Risk Would Be a Grave Mistake (US Senate Committee on Environment and Public Works)
articles.author: Public Technologies
articles.summary: Sheldon Whitehouse (D-R.I.) is urging the International Monetary Fund to continue analyzing the risks that climate change poses to the economy. In 10 to 15 years, there are going to be regions of the country where you can't get a mortgage because of climate change.

articles.title: Nigeria: Again, Federal Government Places Ekiti, Osun On Flood Alert
articles.author: Bidon Mibzar
articles.summary: The National Early Warning Center (FEW Centre) has issued flood alerts for Ado-Ekiti, Ijero- Ekiti and Ilesa in Ekiti State. In Osun State, there will be flooding due to possible heavy rainfall within the period of prediction in October, 2025. FCT has the highest number of locations on the list.

articles.title: Malaria surge in Southern Africa sparks alarm: Zimbabwe among worst hit
articles.author: Stephen Jakes
articles.summary: Zimbabwe, Botswana, eSwatini, and Namibia are reporting new outbreaks of malaria, according to a new report by the Africa Centres for Disease Control and Prevention (Africa CDC). The report highlights a dramatic spike in Zimbabwe, where suspected malaria cases surged to 111,998 with 310 deaths by epidemiological week 23 of 2025. Africa accounts for 95% of all malaria-related deaths.

articles.title: Frost watch: Coldest nights yet coming to Minnesota
articles.author: Meteorologist Sven Sundgaard
articles.summary: Sven Sundgaard is back with a look at Minnesota's weather taking a chilly turn this week. The Twin Cities and southern Minnesota could see their first frost of the season by Wednesday night. However, warmer air returns by the weekend. IPCC warns that Earth is "firmly on track toward an unlivable world" due to climate change.

articles.title: Greenhouse Gases In Earth's Atmosphere Hit New Record
articles.author: Forbes
articles.summary: The global levels for carbon dioxide, methane and nitrous oxide reached unprecedented highs in 2024, according to the World Meteorological Organization's report. The report is based on the latest data from the WHO's World Climate Change Report.    i.e. in 2024.

articles.title: Lake Michigan Sees Near-Record Warm Waters
articles.author: Danielle Kaeding
articles.summary: All five Great Lakes are around 4 to 5 degrees Fahrenheit warmer than their long-term average for the last three decades. Lake Erie may have surpassed the 2021 record for Thursday with surface water temperatures recorded at almost 66 degrees. Lake Superior is about 4.2 degrees warmer than normal at 54.6 degrees. A weak La Niña is expected to favor below normal temperatures throughout this winter.

articles.title: Antarctica's ice melting faster than expected: Scientists
articles.author: Daily Sabah
articles.summary: Antarctica's frozen stability is showing signs of unraveling under the pressure of global warming. Scientists observe increased surface melting, glacier acceleration and glacier shrinkage in the region due to climate change. The ice sheet in Antarctica is melting faster than ever before due to the warming.

articles.title: New Study Shows AMOC Stable, Contradicting Alarmist Narrative
articles.author: Kenneth Richard
articles.summary: Alarmists claim that the Atlantic Meridional Overturning Circulation (AMOC) is on the verge of collapse due to anthropogenic climate change. Sea level rise from New York to Brest, France has been stable, not accelerating, since 1960.

articles.title: Great Lakes seeing near-record warm waters
articles.summary: The Great Lakes are seeing near-record warm water temperatures. All five of the lakes are around 4 to 5 degrees Fahrenheit warmer than their long-term average for the last three decades. Lake Erie may have surpassed the 2021 record for Thursday with surface water temperatures recorded at almost 66 degrees. Lake Michigan has temperatures that are the highest above the average at 62.6 degrees.

articles.title: First 'climate tipping point' being crossed: Coral reefs in crisis, is there still a way back?
articles.author: Ilayda Cakirtekin
articles.summary: Global Tipping Points Report 2025 warns that warm-water coral reefs are crossing their thermal tipping point, undergoing unprecedented dieback, and marking Earth's first climate 'tipping point'. Coral reefs provide habitat for over 800,000 species and generate an estimated $9.9 trillion in goods and services each year, sustaining livelihoods of up to 1 billion people worldwide. Christian Voolstrastra is president of International Coral Reef Society.

articles.title: 'The Blob' May Impact Chicago Winter
articles.author: Andrea Earnest
articles.summary: In 2014, NOAA identified a large marine heat wave that dominated the northeast Pacific Ocean. The 2013-14 winter was the third-coldest and third-snowiest on record in Chicago. La Niña is a climate phenomenon that occurs when the central and eastern Pacific Ocean cools down more than usual. It usually causes the northern U.S. to be cold and wetter than usual and the southern states to be warmer and drier.

articles.title: Why Are New Zealanders Called ‘Kiwis'?
articles.author: Ca Lea Johnson
articles.summary: People from New Zealand are called 'Kiwis' because of a native bird that goes by the same name. The kiwi's popularity skyrocketed in New Zealand during the 19th century when local companies used pictures of the bird to indicate the origins of their products. Kiwis became the country's mascot.

articles.title: One of most vulnerable states to climate change lacks ‘political will' to mitigate its disaster threats
articles.author: Alex Rozier
articles.summary: It's the 20th anniversary of Hurricane Katrina. Mississippi Building Code Council wants a statewide, uniform building code. Legislators passed a statewide building code in 2014, but most cities and counties chose to opt out of it. Insurance Institute for Business & Home Safety ranked Mississippi's building codes near the bottom among coastal states.

articles.title: PM directs urgent measures to brace for Typhoon Fengshen
articles.author: Vietnam
articles.summary: Typhoon Fengshen is the 12th storm to hit the East Sea this year. PM Pham Minh Chinh has issued Official Dispatch No. 200/CD-TTg, directing ministries, agencies, and localities to take urgent, proactive measures to respond to the storm. The storm is expected to strengthen to level 11, gusting to level 13, and may alter its path and intensity as it interacts with cold air from October 21. Central provinces from Ha Tinh to Quang Ngai are forecast to experience widespread, prolonged heavy rainfall.

articles.title: Greenhouse Gases In Earth's Atmosphere Hit New Record
articles.author: David Bressan
articles.summary: The global average level of carbon dioxide is 423.9 parts per million (ppm), the highest since modern measurements started in 1957. Concentrations of methane and nitrous oxide have also risen to record levels. The rise is explained by continued emissions by human activities, an increased frequency and intensity of wildfires, and the reduced capability of ecosystems to trap and store greenhouse gases.

articles.title: Cheaper Green Hydrogen Could Be On The Way
articles.author: Forbes
articles.summary: This week's Current Climate newsletter looks at Rivian's big bet on a small electric SUV and the implications of breaching the 1.5-degree global temperature limit. It also looks at the Rivian bet on the electric SUV, and its implications on the global warming.

articles.title: Geese and swan numbers begin to climb at Freezout Lake; drought impacts migration
articles.author: NBC Montana Staff
articles.summary: There are more geese and swans migrating through Freezout Lake Wildife Management Area near Choteau, Montana. 231 swans landed on Sunday, Oct. 19. The fall migration usually peaks in early November, with an average of 12,000 birds pushing through on peak days.

articles.title: Turkish frost may push global hazelnut prices up 30%
articles.summary: Turkey is the world's largest producer of hazelnuts. A cold snap and heavy rainfall damaged orchards across key growing regions. The adverse weather has affected yields and is expected to raise global prices. The situation highlights what agricultural economists refer to as "climateflation"

articles.title: Turkey frost may push global hazelnut prices up 30%
articles.summary: Turkey is the world's largest producer of hazelnuts. A cold snap and heavy rainfall damaged orchards across key growing regions. The adverse weather has affected yields and is expected to raise global prices. The situation highlights what agricultural economists refer to as "climateflation"

articles.title: Frost and rain slash Turkish hazelnut yields
articles.summary: Turkey is the world's largest producer of hazelnuts. A cold snap and heavy rainfall damaged orchards across key growing regions. The adverse weather has affected yields and is expected to raise global prices. The situation highlights what agricultural economists refer to as "climateflation"

articles.title: Europe's climate is changing fast: Here's how it is affecting people and the economy
articles.author: Rosemary Anthony
articles.summary: Temperatures across Europe are rising at twice the global average. This is leading to more frequent and intense heatwaves, droughts, floods and storms. Climate change isn't just about the weather, it's also about the environment.   iStock

articles.title: Moderate drought status for parts of the Upstate
articles.author: Katherine Noël
articles.summary: It's been a dry fall, leading to a moderate drought for portions of the Upstate. It's been dry since the middle-to-end of October, with only 1.16 inches of rain. The next chance of rain is on Sunday, but models are disagreeing on the forecast.

articles.title: UN report: Caribbean still facing rising climate threats
articles.author: Cnw Reporter
articles.summary: Caribbean nations struggle with deep-rooted inequalities and growing climate risks, according to the Global Multidimensional Poverty Index (MPI) 2025, released by the United Nations Development Programme (UNDP) and the Oxford Poverty and Human Development Initiative (OPHI). It found that 23.5 percent of people living in Small Island Developing States (SIDS) experience multidimensional poverty, which factors in income, access to education, healthcare, housing, sanitation, and energy. Haiti has among the highest poverty levels globally, with more than 40 percent of its population living in multiddimensional poverty. Children are disproportionately affected, with 28 percent living in poverty compared to 13.

articles.title: Opinion - Climate change threatens national security — how are the generals responding?
articles.author: William S. Becker
articles.summary: Trump is ignoring the warnings of the government's top military and intelligence experts about the threat of climate change to national security. The U.S. military's 750 installations across 80 countries are at risk of extreme weather and sea-level rise due to climate change, and half of the 3,500 military infrastructure worldwide has been affected by it.

articles.title: Climate change threatens national security — how are the generals responding?
articles.author: William S. Becker
articles.summary: Trump is ignoring the warnings of the government's top military and intelligence experts about the threat of climate change to national security. The U.S. military's 750 installations across 80 countries are at risk of extreme weather and sea-level rise due to climate change, and half of the 3,500 military infrastructure worldwide has been affected by it.

articles.title: Dreaming of a white Christmas? Farmer's Almanac says keep on dreaming.
articles.author: Alyssa Johnson
articles.summary: Alaska's "Aurora Season" is from late August to late April. Chena Hot Springs is an indoor pool and an adult-only lake for wading outdoors. The road trip to Fairbanks from Seattle is over 2,000 miles long via the Alaska Highway.

articles.title: Robins will return to gardens to eat high-fat food they 'absolutely love'
articles.author: newsdesk@nottinghampost.com
articles.summary: Autumn is a quieter time for garden birds. The RSPB recommends feeding birds high-energy, high-fat foods. It's important to keep bird feeders clean and cleanliness and to keep a regular cleanliness in your garden. The autumn months bring an abundance of natural food for birds.

articles.title: Exact day you may bag an extra hour's sleep as clocks go back in the UK
articles.author: Lauren Haughey
articles.summary: Clocks will fall back by one hour on the last Sunday in October. This marks the end of 'British Summer Time' (BST) which has provided us with extended daylight hours during spring and summer. The UK will remain on GMT until March 29, 2026.

articles.title: Sea levels rising faster than at any time in 4,000 years, study warns
articles.summary: Global sea-level rise is increasing at the fastest rate in at least 4,000 years. Coastal delta regions, especially in China, face heightened risk due to subsidence and human activity. Climate Central has created a map that shows which parts of the world could find themselves threatened by rising sea levels.

articles.title: Tropical development likely in the Caribbean Sea.
articles.author: Jim Howard
articles.summary: Tropical development is likely over the Caribbean Sea this week. Melissa is the next name on the storm list. The northern Caribbean Islands will see heavy rain and gusty winds next week. Nothing looks to develop and impact the Carolinas in the short term.

articles.title: "Oh Watta Night!" returns to OFC for eighth year
articles.summary: Deer activity is increasing in Upstate NY as the leaves change color and the temperatures begin to drop. Experts urge motorists to stay on high alert due to the increased deer activity in the months leading up to winter, as the deer are erratic and dangerous.

articles.title: Study finds lower greenhouse gas emissions from tropical waters
articles.author: China.dot.org
articles.summary: Tropical inland waters emit far less greenhouse gases than previously estimated, according to an international study led by Australia's Charles Darwin University. The study aimed to better understand greenhouse gas emissions in tropical rivers, lakes and reservoirs by collating the data. The tropics cannot be considered as one big emissions hotspot because of its complexity.

articles.title: Inland communities are increasingly vulnerable to rainfall from tropical systems » Yale Climate Connections
articles.summary: Inland communities are increasingly vulnerable to rainfall from tropical systems. More than half the deaths from U.S. hurricanes between 2013 and 2022 were the result of freshwater flooding, according to the National Hurricane Center. Yale Climate Connections is a project of Yale University's Climate Change Institute.

articles.title: Why it is time for us to redouble our efforts in the fight against climate change
articles.author: The Yorkshire Post Letters
articles.summary: There is a report on preparedness to deal with the impact of climate change. Over half of England's best agricultural land is already at risk of serious flooding and an extra 1.7 million properties are expected to be at risk. The death rate from heat amongst the elderly will reach 10,000 per year. The overall cost of the climate change will reach around seven per cent of the economy.

articles.title: Australia's Weather Bureau Skeptical About La Nina Formation
articles.author: Devdiscourse News Desk
articles.summary: Australia's weather bureau is skeptical about the formation of a La Nina weather pattern. La Nina is a weather pattern that could alter rainfall and weather conditions across the Americas, Asia, and Oceania. The current forecast suggests potential variability, with other climatic influences possibly playing a larger role.

articles.title: FG: Africa Losing Billions Annually To Climate-Related Disasters
articles.author: Sunday Ojeme
articles.summary: The Minister of State for Finance, Dr. Doris Uzoka-Anite, spoke at the 2025 West African Insurance Companies Association (WAICA) Education Conference in Lagos. She called for regional collaboration to strengthen insurance responses to the growing threats of climate change. Commissioner for Insurance, Olusegun Omosehin, said climate change is a serious macroeconomic threat reshaping the region's fiscal and financial stability.

articles.title: Sea levels rising faster than they have in 4,000 years, study warns
articles.author: Liam Gilliver
articles.summary: Sea levels are rising faster than at any point in the last 4,000 years. Since 1900, global sea levels have increased at an average rate of 1.5 millimetres a year. Global warming and melting glaciers are driving the rise. Deltas - flat, fertile regions close to the water - will be hit the hardest by rising sea levels.

articles.title: DOE climate report colored by past views of its authors, critics say
articles.author: Scott Waldman
articles.summary: Steve Koonin and four of the five authors that Chris Wright chose to write the government-backed report on climate change were critics of the endangerment finding, a 2009 EPA decision that underpins many federal climate regulations. The report is being used as evidence by EPA Administrator Lee Zeldin to eliminate the endangerments finding.

articles.title: Antarctica's ice melting faster than expected: Scientists
articles.author: Anadolu Agency
articles.summary: Antarctica's frozen stability is showing signs of unraveling under the pressure of global warming. Scientists observe increased surface melting, glacier acceleration and shrinking sea ice similar to trends seen in Greenland. Ice loss has quadrupled since the 1990s, with weakened ice shelves failing to restrain outlet glaciers.

articles.title: La Nina uncertain, says Australia's weather bureau, clouds outlook for farming and weather extremes
articles.summary: La Nina and El Nino are caused by the cooling or warming of ocean surface temperatures in the eastern and central Pacific. La Nina typically brings greater rainfall to eastern Australia, South-east Asia and India with drier weather in the Americas and Oceania. Three consecutive La Nina events between 2020 and 2023 brought plentiful rainfall to Australia, but drought and heatwaves in parts of the Americas.

articles.title: La Nina uncertain, says Australia's weather bureau, clouds outlook for farming and weather extremes
articles.summary: A La Nina weather pattern is not forming and could bring wilder weather to parts of the Americas, Asia and Oceania. La Nina and its analogue, El Nino, are caused by the cooling or warming of ocean surface temperatures in the eastern and central Pacific.

articles.title: Words on Birds: Help birds survive the cold
articles.author: Steve Grinley
articles.summary: Juncos, white-throated and white-crowned sparrows are migrating through Plum Island. Most of the catbirds have headed south, but a few have lingered on the island. The cold nights have made it harder for them to migrate.

articles.title: Disorderly Transition: When Climate And Finance Collide
articles.author: Forbes
articles.summary: Local climate disasters now trigger global economic shocks. Environmental crises and financial systems are intertwined and increasingly fragile, as the author points out.    .      for more information, visit: http://www.cnn.com/2013/01/30/environmental-crises-and-financial-systems-in-depth/

articles.title: Australia Questions La Nina's Weather Patterns Impact in 2023
articles.author: Devdiscourse News Desk
articles.summary: Australia's Bureau of Meteorology remains skeptical about the formation of a La Nina weather pattern. La Nina could alter rainfall and weather conditions across the Americas, Asia and Oceania. The U.S. National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration reported weak La Nina conditions persisting through December, but Australia's climate models have shown significant variability.

articles.title: What are climate tipping points? They sound scary, especially for ice sheets and oceans, but ...
articles.author: Famagusta Gazette
articles.summary: Meltwater runs across the Greenland ice sheet in rivers. The ice sheet is already losing mass and could soon reach a tipping point due to climate change. The book "The Tipping Point: How Little Things Can Make a Big Difference" is written by Alexandra A Phillips.

articles.title: 'Prepare now': heatwave conditions grip east coast
articles.author: Dane Wilson
articles.summary: Extreme heatwave warnings have been issued for much of NSW as temperatures soar more than ten degrees above spring averages. The weather is expected to remain hot for the rest of the week.    in the state. For confidential support call the Samaritans on 08457 90 90 90, visit a local Samaritans branch or click here.

articles.title: The Earth is getting darker
articles.author: Devika Rao
articles.summary: The Earth is going dark. The Northern Hemisphere is reflecting less light than the Southern Hemisphere. Melting Arctic ice and reduced snow cover are actively dimming the glow of the planet. Environmental regulations have reduced aerosol pollution in the NH and increased aerosol levels in the SH.

articles.title: Only 26 days of diesel supply; farm fuel insecurity rises as harvest demand hits
articles.summary: Farm sector is concerned about fuel supply risks amid unstable global conditions. They want the government to address storage vulnerabilities.      Â   in Australia's farm sector is ringing alarm bells over fuel supplies risks.  In Australia, fuel supplies are regulated by the Energy Security Act.

articles.title: Climate risks expose West African insurers to $50bn yearly losses
articles.author: Oluwakemi Abimbola
articles.summary: Climate change is a growing concern for many in West Africa. The World Economic Forum listed Lagos as one of the 11 low-lying cities that may disappear by 2100 without creative solutions to combat rising tides. Africa's insurance market penetration is under 3%. Africa contributes less than 4% of global greenhouse gas emissions. Africa faces $30-50bn in annual losses from climate disasters. The industry manages trillions in assets.

articles.title: Climate activists face two-day court hearing over harbour protest
articles.author: Anna Falkenmire
articles.summary: Climate activists outside Newcastle court on October 20 and kayakers on the harbour on November 24, 2024 are seen in pictures by Marina Neil and Peter Lorimer. They are protesting against climate change in the pictures taken by Peter Lorimier and Marina Neil.

articles.title: Why Does The Climate Have To Change, Why Don't We?
articles.summary: There are miserable climate changes all over India. The reason for this climate change is our foolishness, our laziness and our unwillingness to take actions to change it. We are here enjoying in the AC air while polar bears are suffering in the melted glaciers because of our mistakes.

articles.title: Climate change threatens farmland
articles.summary: Rising sea levels and poor drainage systems are threatening agricultural lands, according to the Minister for Agriculture and Waterways, Tomasi Tunabuna. The government has re-established the national drainage board to improve water management and address waterlogging on farmlands. The Ministry remains concerned about the overall impact of climate change on agricultural productivity in coastal communities.

articles.title: What are climate tipping points? They sound scary, especially for ice sheets and oceans, but there's still room for optimism
articles.summary: As the planet warms, it risks crossing catastrophic tipping points, where Earth systems, such as ice sheets and rain forests, change irreversibly over human lifetimes. Geoscientist Alexandra A Phillips has studied the ocean and climate for over a decade and recently spent a year on Capitol Hill working on bipartisan climate policy.

articles.title: Climate Awareness on the Rise as Pakistanis Rally for Action
articles.author: Pak Tribune
articles.summary: 34 percent of Pakistanis support government-led environmental initiatives. Pakistan is one of the countries most vulnerable to climate change. Without urgent action, Pakistan could face economic losses of up to 20 percent of its GDP by 2050. The report also exposes a worrying trust gap in rural Pakistan.

articles.title: India's climate war is missing its first responders—urban local bodies
articles.author: Kamil Saiyed
articles.summary: India's first responders are underpowered, underfunded and unprepared for climate change adaptation. Urban Local Bodies (ULBs) are the ideal institutional bodies for this work as their mandates overlap with climate sensitive sectors like water, housing, waste, and public health. ULBs need to be empowered with real fiscal and administrative autonomy and space for community participation.

articles.title: Illawarra beach erosion: When is sand loss a natural cycle and when is it a real threat?
articles.author: Cookie Pnigdbxqzpgpjmu
articles.summary: "That allows us to look at, really fine scale, where the changes are occurring to be better prepared for climate-induced changes to the storm activity or even sea level rise," Mr McLaughlin said.    .   "We need to be prepared for the future."

articles.title: Cyclone Alert Issued for Andaman and Nicobar Islands: IMD Warns of Intense Weather Conditions
articles.author: Devdiscourse News Desk
articles.summary: The IMD has warned of a potential cyclone affecting the Andaman and Nicobar Islands. The cyclone is predicted to intensify from October 21. Intense thunderstorms accompanied by gusty winds and lightning are expected in the region on October 21, 22, and 23.

articles.title: Record Heat, Fire Risks Soar in Severe Weather Update
articles.author: Mirage News
articles.summary: Record heat and elevated fire dangers are set to impact much of central and eastern Australia in the coming days. The maximum temperature forecast for this afternoon is in the low to mid-40s in parts of South Australia, Queensland and north-western parts of New South Wales. On Wednesday, the focus will shift to eastern parts of NSW with high fire dangers due to the combination of heat and strong winds.

articles.title: Africa can do more than participate in the climate change conversation
articles.summary: In November, world leaders, scientists, non-governmental organisations, and civil society will convene in Brazil for the COP30 to discuss priority actions needed to tackle climate change. In the past, Africa has approached the global conversation on climate change merely as a victim of inequitable climate finance. Now, African leaders adopted the Addis Ababa Declaration positioning Africa as a key architect of climate solutions focusing on resilience and green development.

articles.title: East coast to sizzle after record October temperatures in Australia's west
articles.author: The Guardian
articles.summary: Temperatures in Australia's eastern states are expected to reach up to 18C above average over the coming week. BoM calls it "a very big day of weather" for Australia's east states.       .   - BoM

articles.title: [뉴스9 날씨] Tomorrow morning, early cold... Frost and ice everywhere inland
articles.author: Omar El Sayed
articles.summary: Temperatures in South Korea have dropped by 8 degrees in a day. The dramatic temperature drop is advancing the season by nearly a month in a single day. East coast is bracing for heavy rains, while higher elevations in Gangwon-do are already seeing snow and frost and frozen water are anticipated overnight. High sea waves pose a hazard to maritime activities.

articles.title: Melbourne's Decline: Why Residents Now Rank the City as Australia's Least Livable
articles.author: Internewscast
articles.summary: Melbourne is at a crossroads, according to Committee for Melbourne and Ipsos' 2025 Living in Melbourne Report. Many residents are worried about their city's safety and security. Many are fed up with daily reports of home invasions, carjackings, armed robberies, and machete and knife attacks dominating the headlines. Half of Melburnians can't afford to live in their preferred suburb due to soaring cost-of-living pressures. The number of people who don't identify as Melburnian has almost doubled in the past year.

articles.title: Study: Emissions from top meat and dairy companies rival those of Saudi Arabia
articles.author: Subhra Battacharjee
articles.summary: A new report details the climate impact of meat and dairy companies. The report details how methane emissions from the sector could push temperature up. The world's largest meat and milk companies are responsible for a lot of greenhouse gasses that contribute to climate change.

articles.title: Study: Emissions From Top Meat and Dairy Companies Rival Those of Saudi Arabia
articles.summary: Combined emissions from the world's top meat and dairy producers are on par with those of the biggest fossil fuel companies and higher than those of Saudi Arabia. Agriculture is the second-largest source of global CO2 emissions after fossil fuel emissions. The world's 1.5°C warming limit may be breached even earlier than originally thought.

articles.title: The 12 Peterborough streets most affected by fly-tipping revealed
articles.author: Stephen Briggs
articles.summary: There were 21,269 incidents of fly tipping reported in Peterborough between September 2023 and August 2025. Lincoln Road, Gladstone Street and Cromwell Road have had the most reports of fly-tipping in the city in the past two years, according to a Freedom of Information Request.

articles.title: Climate change is about to case the world to add 57 "superhot" days per year, but studies show it could have actually been much, much worse. Which means we actually made progress. Which means SUVs FOR EVERYONE WOO-HOOOO (apnews.com) 0
articles.summary: Climate change is about to add 57 "superhot" days per year, but studies show it could have been much worse, so it's good that we've made progress. This means SUVs are going to be cheaper and easier to buy, so people will buy SUVs.

articles.title: Climate Change, Water Management Affect Basin
articles.author: Mirage News
articles.summary: The Murray-Darling Basin is getting hotter due to climate change. This will impact the Basin directly through reductions in rainfall decreasing river flows and water availability, and indirectly through other risks such as the increased threat of bushfire. Extreme weather events like bushfires and floods are adding more stress to the environment.

articles.title: Is China saving the planet?
articles.author: Graham Pockett
articles.summary: China is opening a new coal-fired power station every few days. China is the world's largest emitter of carbon dioxide (CO²). The current level of CO² in the atmosphere sits at 420ppm and is slowly increasing. The theory of greenhouse gasses causing global warming was originally presented by Svante Arrhenius in the early 1900s.

articles.title: 'Series of records broken': 'Really hot' temperatures to scorch NSW this week, as storms and wind hit parts of nation's south-east
articles.author: Preston Potts
articles.summary: Temperatures in excess of 40C are expected in parts of New South Wales this week. Strong winds and rain are forecast to converge over the nation's south-east. The Bureau of Meteorology has issued a severe weather warning for damaging winds in Western, Upper Derwent Valley, South East, East Coast, Central Plateau, Midlands, North East, North West Coast and Central North Forecast Districts.

articles.title: East coast to sizzle after record October temperatures in Australia's west
articles.author: Petra Stock
articles.summary: October heat records are set to fall this week across South Australia, Queensland and New South Wales, while Sydney and Brisbane can expect peaks in the high 30s. High fire danger is expected across WA, Queensland, northern SA, and NSW on Wednesday. Australia's land surface has warmed by 1.5C since 1910.

articles.title: Researchers issue warning after making troubling discovery on expedition to Antarctica: 'We may see more'
articles.author: Hannah Slusher
articles.summary: Antarctic sea ice has reached its third-lowest level since satellite tracking began nearly 50 years ago. Warming ocean waters are eroding Antarctic stability. Nations are expanding marine protected areas to safeguard polar ecosystems and investing in satellite monitoring networks that track ocean heat and ice loss in real time.

articles.title: Typhoon Fengshen targets Hue - Quang Ngai, floods and landslides expected
articles.author: Vietnamnet News
articles.summary: Fengshen strengthens as it nears the coast from Hue to Quang Ngai. There are widespread rain and flooding risks due to heavy downpours and strong winds.   Â. Â   y  y   in Vietnam.

articles.title: The missing link: three things needed for proper environmental protections
articles.author: Nicole Forrester
articles.summary: Australia's clean-energy transition is accelerating and so are the claims that it's harming nature, as well as the claims it's good for the environment.   iReport.com will bring you more information as it comes to hand.  iReporter.com

articles.title: Sanwo-Olu to Host Global Summit on Blue Economy, Coastal Resilience Ahead Cop30
articles.author: Nigeria
articles.summary: Lagos State Governor, Babajide Sanwo-Olu Sunday reaffirmed the state's commitment to advancing sustainable growth through innovation and investment in resilience as it hosts the 2025 International Climate Change Summit. The 2025 Summit with the theme: 'Blue Economy, Green Money: Financing Africa's Coastal Resilience and Ocean Innovation' will be held at the Lagos Continental Hotel between the 6th and 7th of November. The event will convene to accelerate action and invest in Africa's coastal and ocean economies ahead of the 2025 UN Climate Change Conference.

articles.title: Urgent warning about brutal heatwave about to strike Australia as temperatures break records
articles.author: NICHOLAS WILSON
articles.summary: Aussies are expected to suffer through an abnormally hot summer with a higher risk of severe weather. The Bureau of Meteorology's long-range forecast predicts maximum temperatures will be higher than average nationwide over the four months leading up to February next year. November is expected to record higher-than-average rainfall across much of northern and eastern Australia. The NSW coastline is the only part of the country likely to avoid the extreme weather.

articles.title: Families forced to relocate amid worsening crisis on US island: 'This is a continually degrading situation'
articles.author: Geri Mileva
articles.summary: Louisiana was given a $48.3 million grant to help relocate 37 families living on the Isle de Jean Charles. Sen. Sheldon Whitehouse said it's a continually degrading situation. The situation mirrors the growing global trend of ecological displacement. The state's Coastal Protection and Restoration Authority has led initiatives to reduce land loss.

articles.title: Albo has destroyed the consensus on migration
articles.author: Tarric Brooker
articles.summary: The level of migration remains a hotly contested issue in Australia. 41% of Australians now say that migration is 'generally positive' for the country, while 41% say it's negative for the nation. The majority of people used to consider migration to be a positive thing.

articles.title: Aussies sweat through record-breaking heat
articles.summary: It's been a scorching hot weekend for much of the country. The heat has settled over western and central parts of Australia. It will continue for several days, bringing hot, dry and windy conditions as it moves into central NSW on Wednesday. The fire danger could spread into parts of the Illawarra. Rain is set to hit South Australia, Victoria and parts of NSW this week. It's going to be windy and wet in Tasmania.

articles.title: Aussies sweat through record-breaking heat, severe thunderstorms forecast
articles.author: Alexandra Feiam
articles.summary: Record-breaking temperatures continue to hit parts of Australia this week. The heat is expected to continue for several days, bringing dry, windy and soggy conditions. The fire danger is high in parts of Western Australia, Queensland and northern parts of South Australia on Monday and Tuesday. The weather will get worse in the southeast, with thunderstorms and damaging winds.

articles.title: Global study shows intensifying drought may wreck grasslands
articles.summary: As droughts become longer and more severe, grasslands worldwide tend to undergo breakdown. The study involved scientists from Beijing Forestry University and their counterparts from over 120 institutions, including Colorado State University in the United States. They tracked plant growth in 74 grasslands and shrublands across six continents during drought. After four consecutive years of extreme drought, productivity losses increased by approximately 2.5 times compared with the first year.

articles.title: BHP urges Australia to speed up approvals and lower power costs to stay competitive
articles.author: Yieh Corp
articles.summary: Geraldine Slattery, BHP's Australia head, said on October 15 that the country must accelerate environmental approvals and lower power costs to attract mining investment and compete globally. She warned that lengthy permitting processes hinder Australia's competitiveness against nations such as the US.

articles.title: Urgent warning about brutal heatwave about to strike Australia as temperatures break records
articles.author: The Daily Mail
articles.summary: Millions of Australians are set to sweat through the hottest October week in nearly two decades. South Australia, Queensland, NSW, and the ACT could all break their heat records for October, with temperatures expected to hit the mid-40s. Weatherzone has warned of an abnormally hot summer.

articles.title: Global study revises greenhouse gas emissions for tropical inland waters (Charles Darwin University)
articles.author: Public Technologies
articles.summary: Tropical inland waters don't produce as many greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions as previously. Lowland tropical rivers emit large quantities of greenhouse gases, with rates influenced by seasonal flooding. Jenny Davis has taken an aerial photo of the South Alligator River and floodplain in Northern Territory, Australia.

articles.title: Why many Melbourne residents now think the city is the WORST in Australia: 'The future ...
articles.author: The Daily Mail
articles.summary: Melburnians believe their city has gone backwards over the past year due to a spike in violent crime. Research by the Committee for Melbourne and Ipsos found a growing number of residents feel unsafe.       i.e. they are worried about their city's security.

articles.title: Head of ABS defends debunking far-right ‘mass migration' claims after censorship accusations
articles.author: The Observer
articles.summary: David Gruen, Australia's chief statistician, has defended the Australian Bureau of Statistics' recent debunking of far-right claims of 'mass migration'. The biennial World Stats Day on 20 October comes amid concerns that the statistics agency is not independent enough.

articles.title: Climate change threatens farmland
articles.author: FBC News
articles.summary: Rising sea levels and poor drainage systems are threatening agricultural lands, according to the Minister for Agriculture, who is concerned about sea level rise and drainage problems in the area.       .   in this context.  in the context

articles.title: Global Study Revises Greenhouse Gas Emissions For Tropical Inland Waters
articles.author: Mirage News
articles.summary: Tropical inland waters don't produce as many greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions as previously estimated. The study was conducted by Charles Darwin University and academics from Australia, Singapore, China, Belgium, Switzerland, Germany, Sweden, Austria, Canada, France, United States and the Netherlands.

articles.title: Türkiye hosts forest innovation week, focusing on wildfire threats
articles.author: Source: Xinhua
articles.summary: Türkiye inaugurated the Istanbul Forest Innovation Week on Monday. It's gathering delegates from 75 countries, 30 international organizations, and over 400 experts to address growing wildfire threats exacerbated by climate change. The five-day event features discussions on AI, drones, and satellite monitoring for wildfire management.

articles.title: Study finds lower greenhouse gas emissions from tropical waters
articles.author: Source: Xinhua
articles.summary: Tropical inland waters emit far less greenhouse gases than previously estimated, according to an international study led by Australia's Charles Darwin University. Greenhouse gases, mainly carbon dioxide, methane, and nitrous oxide, trap heat in the atmosphere and are naturally released from inland waters. Human activities greatly increase these emissions.

articles.title: Australia accuses China of 'unsafe' military jet maneuvers
articles.author: Saudi Gazette
articles.summary: A Chinese military aircraft released flares in close proximity to a patrol jet over the South China Sea. The Australian government has raised its concern with Beijing about the incident. The incident has been reported to the Australian government by the Chinese military.

articles.title: Forecast points to variable winter conditions (Iowa Farm Bureau Federation)
articles.author: Public Technologies
articles.summary: La Niña conditions are expected to settle in this winter, bringing variable weather across Iowa. The latest North Central U.S. Climate and Drought Outlook indicates that much of the region will experience cooler conditions with La Niña this winter. The outlook was presented on Oct. 16.

articles.title: Indigenous groups sidelined in Indonesia's climate efforts
articles.author: The Jakarta Post
articles.summary: Indigenous communities in Indonesia continue to bear heavy burdens from the climate crisis impact. Indonesia is home to more than 2,000 indigenous people. They are losing their homes and livelihoods and face environmental disasters. They engage in little to no meaningful participation in mitigation and adaptation efforts.

articles.title: Extreme drought conditions leave N.L. homesteader adapting to a lower water supply
articles.author: CBC
articles.summary: Steve McBride moved to N.L. 12 years ago because he thought it would be less affected by climate change than other regions, but it's mid-October and his well is near ground-level. He's worried about the future of his homestead.

articles.title: Australia's wheat production outlook improves as harvest begins
articles.author: system
articles.summary: Analysts have raised their estimates for Australia's wheat harvest as better-than-expected yields in the Reuters poll showed. The Reuters poll was based on the results of the latest crop assessment.      Â   in the survey.

articles.title: Australia Flags China's 'Unsafe' Flare Drop in Aerial Encounter
articles.author: US News
articles.summary: A Chinese fighter jet dropped flares near one of Australia's maritime patrol planes. Australia has raised concerns with Beijing about the incident.   Â   in a statement. In the statement, Australia also expressed its concern with China's response to the incident, which was positive.

articles.title: Here's Why Battlefield 6's 'Completionist' Skin is Getting Torn Apart Online
articles.author: Game Rant
articles.summary: Many believe that Battlefield 6's Heatwave skin variants for the Desert Locusts squad are a disgrace to players' grinds.   Â      in the game are bad for the game and for players' livelihoods. The game's developers are not aware of this.
